item.title: Python
item.description: Add at least one actual blog post about the python stuff we have been working on: this can be anything, but must include some python code that executes in a python code chunk (i.e.,{python} #your code) and includes output (can even be examples from hw assignments, etc). You are encouraged to use reticulate to let R and Python talk to each other in chunks! That way you can do it straight from R markdown in python code chunks.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Using the online demographic research tool ‘Social Explorer’, I gathered data relating to health and demographics for Texas counties in 2017. For each dataset, I chose data pertaining to the first 53 counties in Texas. I originally wanted to look at data from all of the 254 counties in Texas, but I quickly realized that was too much data for this project. In an effort to eliminate bias in choosing which counties to look at, I came up with the idea of choosing the first 53 counties after ordering them alphabetically.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: library(carData) Arrests <- Arrests head(Arrests) ## released colour year age sex employed citizen checks ## 1 Yes White 2002 21 Male Yes Yes 3 ## 2 No Black 1999 17 Male Yes Yes 3 ## 3 Yes White 2000 24 Male Yes Yes 3 ## 4 No Black 2000 46 Male Yes Yes 1 ## 5 Yes Black 1999 27 Female Yes Yes 1 ## 6 Yes Black 1998 16 Female Yes Yes 0 My dataset is called ‘Arrests’ and is from the ‘carData’ package.
